title: VEGOILS-Palm rises for fifth straight session as rival oils gain
text:
VEGOILS-Palm rises for fifth straight session as rival oils gain

SINGAPORE, Oct 29 (Reuters) - Malaysian palm oil futures rose for a fifth consecutive session on Tuesday, tracking gains in rival oils on the Dalian exchange, though weaker EU import data and a stronger ringgit capped gains.

The benchmark palm oil contract for January delivery FCPOc3 on the Bursa Malaysia Derivatives Exchange last traded 0.8% higher at 2,418 ringgit ($578.33) per tonne.

This comes after the contract saw the biggest weekly jump in nearly three years on bullish export sentiment. January palm oil contract DCPF0 on Tuesday last rose 0.6%, while the January soyoil contract DBYF0 traded 0.3% higher. Palm oil on the Dalian reached record highs last week due to a weaker yuan and higher logistic costs, which drove Chinese traders to purchase domestic palm.

Elsewhere, U.S. soyoil futures on the Chicago Board of Trade BOc2 was down 0.1%.

Palm oil is affected by price movements in related oils as they compete for share in the global vegetable oils market.

Limiting palm's gains, however, was a stronger ringgit which appreciated 0.1% against the dollar, making the edible oil more expensive for holders of foreign currencies.

Palm oil imports from the EU in the 2019/20 season that started on July 1 also fell 12% from the year earlier, official data showed on Monday. But a Kuala Lumpur based trader told Reuters that the plunge was expected by the market and did not have a significant impact on prices. oil FCPOc3 may test a resistance at 2,422 ringgit per tonne, a break above which could lead to a gain to 2,461 ringgit, Reuters analyst Wang Tao said. TECH/C

FUNDAMENTALS

* Chicago corn futures slid for a second session, while soybeans lost ground, as progress in the harvest of both crops in the United States weighed on prices. GRA/]

* Oil prices edged lower in quiet trade as concerns about slower economic growth overshadowed signs of a thawing in the trade between Washington and Beijing, while investors awaited U.S. inventory data. O/R

MARKET NEWS

* Asian shared scaled a three-month high after Wall Street hit all-time peaks amid hopes of progress in Sino-U.S. trade talks and for another dose of policy stimulus from the Federal Reserve this week. MKTS/GLOB

* The S&P 500 hit a record high on Monday, while the Nasdaq fell just short of its lifetime high touched in late July as a more civil tone between the United States and China lifted hopes for a possible trade deal and investors looked toward a Federal Reserve rate cut later this week. .N

* Both the dollar and riskier Asian currencies held on to modest overnight gains, amid hopes for an easing in Sino-U.S. trade tensions and as investors waited for direction from this week's Federal Reserve meeting. USD/
